title: Bury handed extension to settle their debts in bid to avoid winding-up the League One club
text:
Bury have been given more time to settle their debts in a bid to avoid a winding-up order.

Lawyers for the club told a specialist insolvency and companies court in London on Wednesday that a further extension was needed to investigate whether the club has paid too much tax to HM Revenue and Customs.

Judge Nicholas Briggs adjourned the case until December 4.

Bury have been given extra time to clear their debts in a bid to avoid a winding-up petition

The Bury Times add that the judge in court was told that the club may have over-paid in tax in PAYE relating to salaries they had not paid. They already handed £7,000 to the tax man.

Bury's Football League membership was withdrawn on August 27 after owner Steve Dale failed to meet a given deadline.

He was asked to provide guarantees that Bury were in a position to fulfil their Sky Bet League One fixtures but the EFL were not satisfied and therefore withdrew the club's position in the division, leaving 23 teams and one less relegation place.

They became the first side to drop out of the EFL since Maidstone were liquidated back in 1992.

A bid to reinstate the club in League Two for the start of next season was rejected by the remaining 71 member clubs of the EFL.
